newsitem.title: VIETNAM: Thomson BankWatch downgrades Vietnam risk rating.
newsitem.headline: Thomson BankWatch downgrades Vietnam risk rating.

text.p: Credit rating agency Thomson BankWatch said in a statement on Wednesday that it had downgraded the sovereign risk rating of Vietnam and lowered the short-term local currency ratings on nine Vietnamese banks.

The agency said the sovereign downgrade, to C from B-, was prompted by increased concern over Vietnam's ability and/or willingness to honour its financial commitments in the face of mounting short-term trade debt and dwindling foreign reserves.

"At the same time, we are additionally concerned by the government's recent directives to local banks regarding the precedence of national banking laws over the country's commitments to international banking conventions," it said.

It said the downgrade of the banks, to the sub-investment grade rating of LC-4, reflected repeated reports of payment delays suffered by international creditors on letter of credit obligations of both private and public sector banks.
"The banking sector has long been characterised by weak management practices, a poor legal framework and alleged widespread corruption..." it said.
It added that these problems had been complicated recently by major fraud cases at local conglomerates, a surge in property speculation and macroeconomic management troubles.

The banks which saw their short-term local currency ratings cut included the flagship state-owned bank Vietcombank and two other state-owned banks, the Bank for investment and Development of Vietnam and the Industrial and Commercial Bank (Incombank).
The six others listed were joint-stock or joint-venture banks.
